Author: gyro_robo
Content:
A trillion dollars can trickle down into quite a few crevices.

I think it's a given that China will want to invest in technology, including start-ups of many sorts. They might dispatch a roving horde of state-appointed VCs to tip the scale. With that kind of money, all bets are off.

They might also toss some billions into existing VC funds, so it expands the pool.\n

Author: redog
Content:
"handing a copied HD-DVD to a friend is stealing"

I don't agree. Handing a copied vhs isn't illegal. Its illegal to sell it to him. Perhaps the license on HD-DVD's is more strictly worded but no one is going to be criminally charged with copying a hd-dvd and giving it to a friend.

"represents a failure to appreciate creation, innovation and the advancement of arts and technology."\nWHAT?! Failure to recognize copying as theft? Tell that to art thieves.

What would happen if copyright law disappeared tomorrow? Would creation, innovation and the advancement of arts or technology halt? Would it slow? Would it grow? I think the fine arts throughout history are much more amazing than the crap hollywood puts out. Did they need copyright law? Why should the right of the cooperate citizen outweigh the right of a fan who would rebroadcast a work at their own expense?

Author: bsaunder
Content:
I keep get the feeling that we (technical folks) are doing a great job of solving our problems while most of the non-technical folks get left behind.

It seems as though if we better understood the world from their perspective, there's a lot of value yet to be create by us for the needs of non-technical people. Generally speaking, creating value is profitable.

Good article.
